data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.1.0-alpha
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a markdown file and add a code block.
2. Type a function, string, etc that has an opening bracket or string

Regardless of the language specified for the code block, bracket completion is not supported.

data.title: [Suggestion] User should get a message if there is no extension installed for VSCode.
data.body:
Testing : https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/6099
- VSCode Version: 1.1.0-alpha
- OS Version: Windows10\Linux\MAC

When there is no extension installed for VSCode then it should display some friendly message like " There is no extension installed for VScode". Right now "code --list-extensions" is not displaying  any message on command prompt.

data.title: Code on insiders started from GUI does not pick up environment variables on Linux
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.0-insider (1f0657703be5609d70088b0385bc27db8cc03a41)
- OS Version: Fedora 23

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Launch vscode-insiders using the app launcher
2. Attempt to build mozilla/gecko-dev with a vscode configuration from nwgh/gecko-vscode and zsh configuration from nwgh/homedir (this uses the "Full Build" task, though I suspect any task would exhibit the same behavior).
3. While the build succeeds, the output is in an unexpected directory.

Let me expand in a way that doesn't involve steps - I use the MOZCONFIG environment variable to tell the firefox build system how to build (what compiler to use, what object directory to use, config options, etc) - this environment variable points to a file that contains the instructions for the build system. When I build from the cli, or from an instance of code started from the cli, this works fine (my environment is picked up just fine). However, when I run from an instance of code started from the GNOME app launcher, my environment is not picked up at all, causing confusion.

I have put minimal files that exhibit this behavior at https://gist.github.com/nwgh/c7b71148908bea753a78685ffad03210

From that gist, `.zshrc` should go in `$HOME`, `mach` should go in some directory (call it `srcdir`), and tasks.json should go in `srcdir/.vscode`. Then, open code, open `srcdir` in code, and run the `Full Build` task.

This worked on 0.10.15-insider (my previous build on the same machine - sorry I don't have a better build to work from for bisecting).

This behavior does not happen on my mac install of the exact same version of code.

For now, I have worked around this by making my build task a shell script that invokes zsh as an interactive shell (to pick up my environment) with a script that calls the firefox build system. I could also likely work around this with os-specific properties in my tasks.json that replicates the work my shell does, or some extra layer of indirection within my mozconfig that replicates the work my shell already does (since a mozconfig is just a shell script). However, that seems... ugly, and prone to break in the future when I inevitably change something in my shell config.

data.title: fixes issue with array iterator
data.body: I have spent the last 2 days digging into this issue.  But it seems if you initialize an element for the treemodel to an empty string `''` there is an issue with the array iterator where the call `itemId = iterator.next()` does actually not return anything when it is supposed to return an item, the last entry in the array.

data.title: ZH-TW | VS Code 1.0 Unable to Work with English Command Correctly
data.body:
![screen](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/18434825/15028289/f336ac88-11fc-11e6-9af1-e93075cfc5ee.png)
Steps to Reproduce:
1. execute "code . --locale=zh-tw" in command prompt to launch VS Code 1.0 with Chinese Taiwan UI.
2. press "F1" to show command palette and try to input ">configure".
3. input Chinese Traditional chars ">設定" instead.
   (please refer to my screenshot attached)

result:
No result for searching keywords started from "configure", but searching "設定" worked.

expectation:
"Commands" in command palette should not be localized.

In addition, the issue here is not about the “searchable”. It is how the user input command.
For example, if a user wants to switch to a git branch, he inputs >git: branch in EN locale of VSCode. (and “git branch” in command prompt)
But in zh-tw locale, “>git: branch” command doesn’t work, and user have to input “>git: 分支” instead.
I believe most of the local developers won't use IME to input Chinese characters for command input.

So, I suggest we can support the command in both English and localized string (e.g. Chinese Traditional)
Thanks.
Terry

data.title: externalConsole: true does not open terminal, just hangs
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version: osx 10.11.4

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create launch.json
   
   ``` json
   {
     "version": "0.2.0",
     "configurations": [
         {
             "name": "Launch",
             "type": "node",
             "request": "launch",
             "program": "${workspaceRoot}/dist/index.js",
             "stopOnEntry": false,
             "args": [],
             "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}/dist/",
             "preLaunchTask": null,
             "runtimeExecutable": null,
             "runtimeArgs": [
                 "--nolazy"
             ],
             "env": {
                 "NODE_ENV": "development"
             },
             "externalConsole": true,
             "sourceMaps": false,
             "outDir": null
         },
         {
             "name": "Attach",
             "type": "node",
             "request": "attach",
             "port": 5858,
             "address": "localhost",
             "restart": false,
             "sourceMaps": false,
             "outDir": null,
             "localRoot": "${workspaceRoot}",
             "remoteRoot": null
         }
     ]
   }
   ```
2. Press F5.

**What happens**: Debug-bar shows. If one goes to debug view, a small dot moves left to right, above _VARIABLES_.

**Expected**: A terminal should open.

If I change `externalConsole` to `false`, I can debug as normal _inside_ vscode, but without any stdin.

data.title: May Iteration Plan
data.body:
This plan captures what we **work on during May** and will **ship early June**.

We arrived at the following themes for May:
- Work on highly requested UI features (tabs, integrated terminal).
- Make a repository with the Monaco/standalone editor available.
- Continue to do some UI explorations.

The [May Test Plan items](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues?q=is%3Aopen+label%3Atestplan-item+milestone%3A%22May+2016%22) are created as issues get closed.

For more information about our development process please refer to the development process [page](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/wiki/Development-Process).
### Schedule

The goal is to make the May update available by the following dates.

End game dates (we end an iteration with an [endgame](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/wiki/Development-Process#end-game))
##### Monday, May 23
- [x] Code freeze at end of day
- [x] Test plan input done at 9 pm Zurich time
- [x] Prepare blog post about more frequent update of `insider` channel
##### Tuesday, May 24
- [x] Test plan ready
- [x] Test build done
- [x] Testing
##### Wednesday, May 25
- [x] Testing
- [x] Fixing
##### Thursday, May 26
- [x] Fixing
- [x] Run OSS tool
- [x] Verification
- [x] Update release notes
##### Friday, May 27
- [x] Fixing (only critical bugs)
- [x] Smoketest
  - [x] Windows - @alexandrudima  
  - [x] OS X - @sandy081  
  - [x] Linux - @joaomoreno 
- [x] All release notes updated 
  - [x] @aeschli
  - [x] @alexandrudima 
  - [x] @dbaeumer 
  - [x] @stevencl  
  - [x] @jrieken 
  - [x] @joaomoreno 
  - [x] @isidorn 
  - [x] @egamma 
  - [x] @sandy081 
  - [x] @Tyriar 
  - [x] @weinand
- [x] Acknowledge pull requests in release notes - All 
- [x] All issues verified
- [x] Satellite modules ready, version updated, smoke tested
  - [x] vscode @bpasero 
  - [x] yo generator @aeschli 
  - [x] vsce @joaomoreno 
  - [x] node debug @weinand 
##### Monday, May 30
- [x] build `insider` release
- [x] sanity check `insider` release
  - [x] Windows - @dbaeumer 
  - [x] OS X - @joaomoreno 
  - [x] linux - @weinand 
- [x] Release `insider` channel
##### Monday, June 6
- [x] build `stable` release
- [x] sanity check `stable` build
  - [x] Windows - @sandy081  
  - [x] OS X - @jrieken  
  - [x] linux - @weinand 
- [x] Release `stable` channel - **Redmond**
##### Tuesday, June 7
- [x] Change `insider` channel to take over role from `alpha`
- [x] Retire `alpha` channel
### Plan Items

| Mark | Description |
| --- | --- |
| :runner: | work in progress |
| :hand: | task is blocked |
| :muscle: | stretch goal for this iteration |
#### Debt Items

This section lists items to reduce our engineering debt:
- [ ] :runner::muscle: Extract the MarkDown editing support into an extension  #6106 @kieferrm 
#### Feedback

Issues to address feedback from the community:
- [x] :runner: UI - Tabs - support stacks in editor groups, expose stacks in an `open editors` pane (was working files)  #224 @bpasero @isidorn 
  - Test #6536 
  - [x] Release notes
- [x] UI - Add an integrated terminal #143 @Tyriar
  - Test #6654 
  - [x] Release notes
- [x] :runner: Editor - Support that the Monaco editor can be consumed standalone @alexandrudima
  - Define 1.0 version of the API
  - Support to contribute new language outside of the editor source tree
  - Test #6655 
  - [x] Release notes
- [x] API - Expose the diff editor in the API #1865 @jrieken

  - [x] Release notes
- [x] CSS: Variables should offer same support as SASS/LESS variables #3077 @sandy081 
  - Test #6656

- [x] Install - Support to install/update an extension from the command line #691 @joaomoreno 
  - Test #6099

- [x] UI - Intellisense support to disable word completions, to address #5574 @jrieken

- [x] Debug - Support to start a debug session from an extension: #4615 @isidorn

#### Engineering

This section lists several engineering/development items that the team identified:

#### Explorations

#### Deferred from May

- :running: Debug - Debugging with babel-register (dynamic sourcemaps) + NodeJs does not work #5728 @weinand 
- UI Open custom terminal for OS X #5462 @Tyriar
- UI - Support to increase the font size used by IntelliSense #2465 @joaomoreno 
## Bugs

Bugs assigned to the current milestone:
- [vscode](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+label%3Abug+-label%3Aupstream+milestone%3A%22May+2016%22)

data.title: TypeScript syntax highlighting breaks on "<{}>"
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.0.0 (1.0.0) 2016-04-13T10:59:46.727Z
- OS Version: Mac OS X 10.11.4 (15E65)

The syntax highlighting in vscode gets confused by `<{}>` in a type declaration in a TSX file:

``` ts
let root: React.ReactElement<{}>;
// syntax highlighting is broken for the rest of the file
```

For example, OK:

![screen shot 2016-05-04 at 2 00 37 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/98301/15023947/bade108e-1200-11e6-92e6-ed1540242e7e.png)

and broken (look at `let` and `if`):

![screen shot 2016-05-04 at 2 00 18 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/98301/15023952/bdf5bda8-1200-11e6-9f54-9fa4a3062d6f.png)

data.title: package.json files for private packages should not warn about missing name and version properties
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version: Mac OS 10.11.4
## Steps to Reproduce
1. Create the following `package.json` file and open it in Code: `{ "private": true }`
2. View the linter warnings (hover over the green squiggles)
## Expected

No warnings, because `npm install` no longer warns about missing names and versions in private packages.
## Actual

Code produces the following warnings:
- Missing property "name"
- Missing property "version"

data.title: Publisher name should not be part of extension name.
data.body:
test : https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/6099 
- VSCode Version: 1.1.0-alpha
- OS Version: Windows10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Launch command prompt and execute command :
 code-alpha --list-extensions or code-alpha --install-extension "cpptools"

Actual: Publisher name is preceded with the extension name and without this user can't install or uninstall extension from command prompt.
Expected: Publisher name should not be required to install and uninstall extension and it should work same like how it is working from command palette : ext install Go

Example: To install CPP extension we need to provide command like:
**code-alpha --install-extension "ms-vscode.cpptools"**
But from command palette we can install with : **ext install cpptools**

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17735796/15022445/8bdaf1be-11e0-11e6-9ff7-354135633655.png)

data.title: Open file via URL creates a "ghost" file in the "working files" section
data.body:
I'm using HoverProvider to provide links to the source file of a Lua function.

The URL is constructed like this:

``` typescript
var url = "file:" + userFunction.sourceFile;
```

(using `file:\\` doesn't seem to work, it triggers the error "file not found" - looks like the `\\` is automatically added after the `file:` protocol?)

The field sourceFile is for example `e:\coh2_mods\ccm\scar\ccm_extensions.scar` (a string value, an absolute path to a physical file)

Clicking this link works and the file is opened. However once the file is edited, which triggers adding the file to the "Working files" list, a ghost file is added to the list instead:
![Ghost file](http://i.imgur.com/pmRO1MB.png)
This file can be edited and the changes seem to save on save as well as long as this file is selected.

Attempting to click this ghost file causes and error (re-select or select after selecting another file):
![Error](http://i.imgur.com/Ay45Bve.png)

Opening the previously clicked file via the workspace explorer and after editing it it is added to the "Workspace files" list:
![Actual file](http://i.imgur.com/BD42WFz.png)
This file behaves correctly. 

Closing the "ghost file" causes the "1 unsaved" notifier to remain. 

**How to test/reproduce?**
1. Prepare a way of clicking a markdown-formatted link in vscode (I used HoverProvider for this) that points to a physical file on your computer
2. Click it. The file should load. Edit it. A ghost file should appear as explained above.

**Note**
The ghost file only started to appear after 1.0.0 update.

data.title: Show error returned from 'callstack' request prominently in CALL STACK view
data.body:
This is related to #5348.

When requesting a backtrace in recent versions of node (v6 and some v5 versions of node that are used in electron), in some situations node runs into an "Internal error: illegal access". Currently node-debug silently ignores this error and returns an empty call stack (which is not very helpful).

Strangely enough fixes node-debug's code injection this problem (but we do not yet understand why).

However there are situations in which code injection doesn't work reliably, e.g. when attaching to an already running node process. To give better feedback to the user in this situation we will have to show the error prominently in the CALL STACK view. (This will help in the 'pause' execution case as well, where the call stack is not available but the CALL STACK view doesn't explain why).

data.title: Test: Command line extension management
data.body:
From #691
- [x] Windows - **@aeschli**
- [x] OS X - **@isidorn**
- [x] Linux - **@dbaeumer**

The Code command line alias now has the power to list, install and uninstall extensions. Syntax:

```
code --list-extensions
code --install-extension <extension>
code --uninstall-extension <extension>
```

Try to break it. Try using it with a different language, see if NLS works.

data.title: Incorrect and inconsistent text-editor highlighting for C# List<T> across all color themes.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Add the following code to a C# class:
   
   ```
   public void DoSomething(List<int> list)
   {
       var newList = new List<int>();
   }
   ```

`List<int>` as a parameter has no type highlighting. 
As a variable only `int` has the correct type highlighting.
This is inconsistent with any other specified type.
See screenshot of Visual Studio 2015 Community for comparison.

![highlighting](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10201888/15019068/48792790-1214-11e6-8e19-8661c4c318c8.png)

data.title: debug adapter telemetry doesn't honour opt-in/out flag
data.body: The debug layer offers telemetry services to it's adapters but that code path doesn't honour the user setting to opt out of telemetry.

data.title: Using launch.json to do simple tasks (without debug)
data.body:
Hi there,
I'm currently looking for a way to remove the `--debug-brk` parameter passed in scripts in `launch.json` as we currently use `launch.json` to execute some gulp tasks instead of real debugging.

We are trying to achieve a VS-like build menu.

Here is our `launch.json` : 

```
{
"version": "0.2.0",
"configurations": [
    {
        "name": "Build Dev",
        "type": "node",
        "request": "launch",
        "program": "${workspaceRoot}/.vscode/launch_build.js",
        "stopOnEntry": false,
        "args": [],
        "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
        "runtimeExecutable": null,
        "runtimeArgs": [
        ],
        "env": {
            "NODE_ENV": "development"
        },
        "externalConsole": false,
        "sourceMaps": false,
        "outDir": null
    },
    {
        "name": "Build Release",
        "type": "node",
        "request": "launch",
        "program": "${workspaceRoot}/.vscode/launch_build.js",
        "stopOnEntry": false,
        "args": [],
        "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
        "runtimeExecutable": null,
        "runtimeArgs": [
        ],
        "env": {
            "NODE_ENV": "production"
        },
        "externalConsole": false,
        "sourceMaps": false,
        "outDir": null
    },
    {
        "name": "------------------",
    },
    {
        "name": "Clean Dev",
        "type": "node",
        "request": "launch",
        "program": "${workspaceRoot}/.vscode/launch_clean.js",
        "stopOnEntry": false,
        "args": [],
        "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
        "runtimeExecutable": null,
        "runtimeArgs": [
        ],
        "env": {
            "NODE_ENV": "development"
        },
        "externalConsole": false,
        "sourceMaps": false,
        "outDir": null
    },
    {
        "name": "Clean Release",
        "type": "node",
        "request": "launch",
        "program": "${workspaceRoot}/.vscode/launch_clean.js",
        "stopOnEntry": false,
        "args": [],
        "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
        "runtimeExecutable": null,
        "runtimeArgs": [
        ],
        "env": {
            "NODE_ENV": "production"
        },
        "externalConsole": false,
        "sourceMaps": false,
        "outDir": null
    },
    {
        "name": "------------------",
    },
            {
                    "name": "Tests",
        "type": "node",
        "request": "launch",
        "program": "${workspaceRoot}/.vscode/launch_build.js",
        "stopOnEntry": false,
        "args": [],
        "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
        "runtimeExecutable": null,
        "runtimeArgs": [
        ],
        "env": {
            "NODE_ENV": "test"
        },
        "externalConsole": false,
        "sourceMaps": false,
        "outDir": null
    }
]
}
```

This currently works, but with the `--debug-brk` option passed, it takes some time to fire up the gulp task.

We are launching gulp tasks with `child_process`'s `exec` in a small nodeJS script.

data.title: Errors Compiling from Source on Arch Linux
data.body:
Hi,

I have been using [this](https://aur.archlinux.org/packages/visual-studio-code-oss) PKGBUILD for building VScode on Arch Linux but whenever it gets to the stage of running `gulp vscode-linux-x64` it returns this error message:

``` bash
[21:45:49] Starting 'optimize-vscode'...

<--- Last few GCs --->

122514 ms: Mark-sweep 1086.3 (1434.3) -> 1086.3 (1434.3) MB, 1281.1 / 0 ms [allocation failure] [GC in old space requested].
123780 ms: Mark-sweep 1086.3 (1434.3) -> 1086.3 (1434.3) MB, 1265.8 / 0 ms [allocation failure] [GC in old space requested].
125094 ms: Mark-sweep 1086.3 (1434.3) -> 1086.3 (1434.3) MB, 1314.7 / 0 ms [last resort gc].
126388 ms: Mark-sweep 1086.3 (1434.3) -> 1086.3 (1434.3) MB, 1293.1 / 0 ms [last resort gc].


<--- JS stacktrace --->

==== JS stack trace =========================================

Security context: 0x13bd75fc9fa9 <JS Object>
1: addMapping(aka SourceMapGenerator_addMapping) [/home/fusion809/AUR/visual-studio-code-oss/src/vscode-1.0.0/node_modules/concat-with-sourcemaps/node_modules/source-map/lib/source-map-generator.js:~94] [pc=0x16def244cf1a] (this=0x1638bb806d99 <a SourceMapGenerator with map 0x32765b3f7f41>,aArgs=0x326def047751 <an Object with map 0x1662ab3f8ca9>)
2: /* anonymous */(aka /* anonymous */) ...

FATAL ERROR: CALL_AND_RETRY_LAST Allocation failed - JavaScript heap out of memory
/home/fusion809/AUR/visual-studio-code-oss/PKGBUILD: line 41: 8995 Aborted (core dumped) gulp vscode-linux-${_vscode_arch}
==> ERROR: A failure occurred in build().
Aborting...
```

Changing `gulp vscode-linux-x64` to `gulp vscode-linux-x64 --max_new_space_size=2000000` (in accordance with [this](http://stackoverflow.com/a/26094800/1876983) answer at StackOverflow) makes no difference to this error. Likewise changing `gulp vscode-linux-x64` to `gulp vscode-linux-x64 --max_new_space_size=16000000` makes no difference. So I suspect there is a deeper issue here. 

Thanks for your time,
Brenton

data.title: Allow html/markdown in displaymessages

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Allowing html/markdown in window.show*Message() would be nice. e.g. ``` vscode.window.showInformationMessage('Woohooit

worked

"); ```

data.title: mac - workspace history lost when showing app windows

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: One of the mission control features in the mac is to rearrange the desktop to only show windows from a certain app. This work with VS Code but until recently I would also see a list of recently opened workspaces at the bottom of the desktop. That allows rapid switching between workspaces and is now gone...

data.title: Repl: reveal on error or reduce minimal height
data.body:
My use case is to run tests within VS Code and be notified when tests break. For this I have the repl always visible below the editor. I find the minimal height of the repl to be quite large, it could be smaller, maybe small enough that I only see 1 line of output (= the test result).

Alternatively it would be cool if the repl would only show if my test run failed. In other words, if the process spawned exits with non zero exit code, reveal the repl (provided as option).

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/900690/15007154/ef624386-11d6-11e6-972a-965b439d4c26.png)

data.title: Typescript class field types don't have the 'type' class
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. ![](http://puu.sh/oFFik/dfd047fab7.png)
2. ![](http://puu.sh/oFFwh/edc55d6ba5.png)

The typescript syntax server doesn't give class field types the `type` class, and the colon and type are not split apart as they are for other types. Because of this, there is not currently a way to style them with other types.

(For reference, this is the scope that I'm using to colour the other locations of types: `type.cover, type.name - variable, type.operator - variable, type.square, type.support`)
